commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've added a quick test of the soft core forcefields and have also finished adding the soft version
of the reaction field forcefield to InterSoftCLJFF and InterGroupSoftCLJFF

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've merged in the update to InterCLJPotential that applies an atom-based cutoff to the LJ
terms when the force-shifted or reaction field cutoffs are used.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've updated the InterCLJPotential so that it also uses an atom-based cutoff for the LJ terms
when the force-shifted or reaction-field potentials are used.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Merged in the clean-up of IntraCLJPotential, together with the move to atom-based cutoffs
for the LJ terms

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've cleaned up the IntraCLJPotential code and have changed the reaction field and force shifted
cutoffs to also apply an atom-based cutoff to the LJ terms

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Committed the changes to IntraCLJPotential that ignore the 1-4 terms when applying the 
force-shifted or reaction field potentials

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've modified the intramolecular CLJ forcefield so that the reaction field is not
used for 1-4 interactions (any pair terms with a scaling factor that is not equal
to one). Testing shows that this gives the same energies as OpenMM, however further
testing on a protein system shows weird behaviour that I must now examine...

commits.message: Fixed some small bugs in the intramolecular reaction field terms

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've updated CLJPotential so that the reaction field term can be applied to the 
intramolecular CLJ potential as well as the intermolecular CLJ potential

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Added the SSE version of the reaction field potential together with a quick test script
that compares the reaction field, group-based and force-shifted cutoffs for different
cutoff lengths in a water box.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Merged the devel branch changes made since Gaetano's branch was created into Gaetano's branch.

This adds the Grid forcefields, fixes compile issues on Mountain Lion, adds the force shifted
and reaction field cutoffs etc.

The code will need checking and testing to sort out any problems with conflicts.

svn command was:

svn merge -r 1546:1653 ../../devel .

Code is uncompiled and untested

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've implemented the reaction field potential in the InterCLJPotential (InterCLJFF and InterGroupCLJFF).
This will be used to allow comparison with OpenMM, and also to let us test reaction field against
other cutoff methods. The code compiles but has not been tested. It should not be used now.

commits.message: Committing the python wrappers for the CLJ forcefields using the reacton field cutoff potential

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've fixed a small bug in the GridFF forcefield that caused unnecessary computation or a
crash when one of the molecule groups was empty.

Code compiles, links and appears to work

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Fixed a small bug in the SSE versions of the soft core CLJ potential that meant that the LJ
energy was incorrectly calculated. While this was a bug, it was not present in anyone's simulations
as the softcore SSE code was disabled (probably because I gave up looking for this bug before!).

Code appears to be working, and now I have tested that the softcore and normal shifted
electrostatics code gives the correct answers. It should be ok now to play with this,
with the normal caveat that this is very new code.

commits.author: bjolong@gmail.com
commits.message: Changes needed to get this to compile on Ben's linux virtual machine... :-)

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've now added the force shifted coulomb potential to the soft core CLJ forcefields. Again, everything
compiles and seems to work, but please don't yet use this code as it needs thorough testing!

(the code is only active if you turn on electrostatic shifting, which I know noone currently
uses!)

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message: ...spoke too soon - missed off a factor of 4!

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've added the force shifting code to InterCLJPotential and IntraCLJPotential, and it seems to work 
quite well. I don't recommend others using this code yet though until it has been thoroughly 
debugged - it is, in effect, a completely new coulomb energy calculation pipeline!

Code compiles, links and runs

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've made the shift-electrostatics part of CLJPotential use the force shifted electrostatics function
used in GridFF. It seems to work for InterGroupCLJFF. Do not use electrostatic shifting in any
other code until I have got it all working...

Code compiles, links and runs.

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've moved GridFF over to using the shifted force cutoff for the electrostatics. This provides a smooth
change in electrostatic energy as a function of cutoff

Code compiles, links and runs and appears to be working

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Commit of the updated python wrappers that fix compilation on Mountain Lion. Sire compiles links and
runs well on this system, and I now need to check that it still works on older macs and linux...

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
End of changes needed to get Sire to compile on Mountain Lion. Going to test that these
don't interfere with compilation on anything else...

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
Some changes to help the python wrappers to compile...

Also, this version works with Lion, so the changes for Mountain Lion don't appear to have affected compilation on Lion

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've fixed a small bug in GridFF that meant that the grid was not recalculated when
the cutoff or buffer size was changed...

commits.author: chryswoods@gmail.com
commits.message:
I've had to make lots of small changes to the code so that it can compile using the compiler
supplied with OS X Mountain Lion. The compiler has become even more picky, particularly when
it comes to order of definition of template classes during partial instantiation...

Corelib code compiles and appears to work - now compiling the python wrappers and
am going to test this on linux and OS X Lion...

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message: Fixed a bug which caused the GridFF forcefield to ignore the value of coul_cutoff

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message: Removed a warning message that was warning about somethign innocuous!

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Fixed a small bug in calculating the dimensions of the grid (forgot to subtract 1 when
calculating the maximum dimensions of the grid)

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Fixed a bug that caused an infinite loop is numerical imprecision caused
the molecule to be moved outside the reflection sphere.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Fixed a bug that caused the grid to be recalculated when part of a molecule that was in group 2,
(but not the part that was in group 2) was moved.

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've fixed a bug that causes a crash when disconnected parts of a molecule are added
to a CLJ forcefield.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
The python wrappers associated with the new GridFF

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've added code so that if any molecule of group 0 moves out of the grid in GridFF, then 
the grid is recalcualted. I've also added code to monitor the errors using the grid
and short cutoff and to output them as a histogram. These show that the errors
are acceptably small, using a 6 A LJ cutoff and a 0.25 A grid.

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've optimised the grid code and now the GridFF looks like it is working really well and 
really quickly :-)

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've fixed the LJ bug in GridFF (which now works!) and have also fixed bugs in the reflection
sphere moves in RigidBodyMC which were caused by numerical imprecision errors.

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've now integrated delta support into GridFF, so that only the changed energies are 
calculated. For some reason, this has stopped the calculation of LJ energies....

Code compiles, links and runs, but GridFF gives the wrong output!

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message: Here are the updated python wrappers for GridFF

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've further optimised the GridFF code and it is now about 20 times faster than the 
explicit calculation, with very stable and small errors :-). See test/SireMM/testgridff.py
if you want to try.

Code is working

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
The energy is now calculated correctly on the grid and is extremely close to the 
exact energy :-). I can now start optimising the code and getting it ready to
be used in the MC test.

Here are the associated python wrappers for GridFF...

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've implemented about 80% of the GridFF forcefield, having written the code to calculate
the explicit coulomb and LJ energies, and also populating the grid with coulomb
potentials.

Code is broken (but compiles)

commits.message: Free energy calculation new hamiltonian

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've added in a GridFF which allows optimisation of the InterGroupCLJFF by calculating
the energy of group 1 on a grid that is generated from the fields of group 2. The code
is not yet implemented - at the moment, this is just a derivation from InterGroupCLJFF,
and I have just added in placeholders and the tests for this code.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Committing the code that allows the EnergyMonitor to use a soft-core potential between
the molecules between the two groups.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Committing the new EnergyMonitor wrappers that add the capability to have soft-core between
the two groups.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
I've fixed a nasty memory leak in PackedArray2D which caused memory to leak when moves
were made on part of a molecule (e.g. a residue in a protein). I've also cleaned up the
way the memory is allocated in these moves, e.g. providing a quick escape for cases
where only the atoms in a single cutgroup are moved.

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message: I've updated sire_python so that you can request a different number of threads at startup

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message: I've changed the way AtomSelection works to try to remove a memory leak

commits.author: chryswoods
commits.message:
Committing the changes to RigidBodyMC that allow a reflection sphere to be
defined. Only molecules within the sphere will be moved, and any moves
that would take molecules out of the sphere are reflected back into the sphere,
thereby keeping everything inside without violating detailed balance.

Code compiles and links, but the reflection sphere code needs to be tested.
